content: Did mammals evolve directly from reptiles?

No, mammals did not evolve directly from reptiles. The relationship between mammals and reptiles is more complex. Both groups evolved from a common ancestor, but they diverged along different evolutionary paths.

Around 320 million years ago, during the Carboniferous period, there was a group of animals called synapsids, which were reptile-like creatures but had some mammalian features. These synapsids are considered the precursors to mammals. Over time, synapsids evolved various mammalian characteristics, such as fur, mammary glands, and a more advanced jaw joint.

Reptiles, on the other hand, evolved from a different branch of the same ancestors. They developed their own set of characteristics, such as scales and the ability to lay eggs on land.

So, in summary, mammals and reptiles share a common ancestor but evolved separately from there. Mammals evolved from synapsids, which were a group distinct from the ancestors of modern reptiles.
